content.description:
Directions:

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>f</mi> </math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> is a real number. Angle measures for trigonometric functions are assumed to be in radians.

Solutions to equations must be real numbers. Determine the exact value of any expression that can be obtained without a calculator. For example, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mn>8</mn></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>cos</mi><mfenced><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mfenced></math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <msup> <mi>sin</mi> <mrow> <mo>-</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </msup> <mfenced> <mn>1</mn> </mfenced> </math> can be evaluated without a calculator.

Unless otherwise specified, combine terms using algebraic methods and rules for exponents and logarithms, where applicable. For example, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>·</mo><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>3</mn></msup></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>5</mn></msup><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></math>, and <math alttext="ln 3 plus ln 5" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>ln</mi><mpadded lspace="-1px"><mn>3</mn></mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>ln</mi><mpadded lspace="-1px"><mn>5</mn></mpadded></math> should be rewritten in equivalent forms.

For each part of the question, show the work that leads to your answers.
content.question:
Part C

​​​The function <math alttext="m"> <mi>m</mi> </math> is given by

<math alttext="m open parentheses x close parentheses equals inverse cosine to open parentheses tan open parentheses 2 x close parentheses close parentheses"> <mi>m</mi> <mfenced> <mi>x</mi> </mfenced> <mo>=</mo> <msup> <mi>cos</mi> <mrow> <mo>-</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </msup> <mfenced> <mrow> <mi>tan</mi> <mfenced> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </mfenced> </mrow> </mfenced> </math>.

Find all values in the domain of <math alttext="m"> <mi>m</mi> </math> that yield an output value of <math alttext="1"><mn>0</mn></math>.

frqParts.text:
Part C

​​​The function <math alttext="m"> <mi>m</mi> </math> is given by

<math alttext="m open parentheses x close parentheses equals inverse cosine to open parentheses tan open parentheses 2 x close parentheses close parentheses"> <mi>m</mi> <mfenced> <mi>x</mi> </mfenced> <mo>=</mo> <msup> <mi>cos</mi> <mrow> <mo>-</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </msup> <mfenced> <mrow> <mi>tan</mi> <mfenced> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </mfenced> </mrow> </mfenced> </math>.

Find all values in the domain of <math alttext="m"> <mi>m</mi> </math> that yield an output value of <math alttext="1"><mn>0</mn></math>.

skill.text: Skill 1.A: Solve equations and inequalities represented analytically, with and without technology.
